Jumps out and successfully disarms Ted by hitting him with a fire extinguisher, showing quick thinking and effective physical response.
Engages in a violent physical struggle but is punched in the throat, falls to his knees gasping for air.
Walks over to dead enemy Ted, takes gun, and says 'Sorry, Ted... but you've been served.'
Spots the fire extinguisher, courageously hurls it at fire, then shoots it to blast out the flames and escape.
Leaps out of the trap door with flames at his heels, manages to remove burning pants quickly, and drags unconscious Saul out just before the barn collapses.
Appears surprised and confused about how they won against their attackers, showing lack of understanding of the situation outcome.
Refuses to leave Saul behind after Saul came to save him.
Asks Red if he is okay after Red is on fire.
Expresses concern about the severed ear and wonders if it could have been found and reattached.
Decides not to abandon Saul after being saved, showing loyalty and moral decisiveness.
Replies calmly and assesses Red's condition when he emerges with fire and injuries, demonstrating situational awareness.
Expresses intention to resolve a personal issue (winning Angie back) despite chaotic circumstances, showing focus.
Considers practical concerns about the severed ear and potential medical remedies, indicating problem-solving tendencies.
Engages in somewhat immature banter about his ear and relationships, which may reflect emotional immaturity impacting judgment.
Shows nervousness and paranoia, but tries to hide it to maintain composure around others.
Listens intently to others' concerns during a tense moment.
Decides to follow a friend into the dark to support him.
Looks over his shoulder nervously but tries to rationalize his paranoia.
Listens intently when Saul tells him to listen for noises.
Decides to follow Red into the dark countryside after the barn fire.
